S4.T1.caption: Table 1: Computation and communication costs of a client in each round: Analysis.
references:
We analyze computation and communication overhead of ProtoFSSL, which is important for resource-constrained clients.
While maintaining the notations used in previous sections, we assume that ΘΘ\Theta is the size of model θ𝜃\theta, F𝐹F is computation cost to run the model θ𝜃\theta for a single datapoint, C𝐶C is the size of a prototype, and RHsubscript𝑅𝐻R_{H} is round interval to update helper clients (for FedMatch). For fair comparison, ProtoFSSL is assumed to consume the entire labeled and unlabeled datasets in an epoch, instead of using random-sampled subsets.
Table 1 shows the results where MixMatch-FedAvg and FixMatch-FedAvg run the SSL methods MixMatch and FixMatch directly on a client. Note that a recent FSSL method FedRGD [52] also uses FixMatch for pseudo-labeling on clients.

S4.T2.caption: Table 2: Per-client computation and communication costs in each round: An example when using ResNet9 and CIFAR-10 as in Table 3.
S4.T2.table:
Methods Comp. cost Comm.cost
MixMatch-FedAvg 782.0 GFLOP 52.6 MB
FedRGD (or FixMatch-FedAvg) 782.0 GFLOP 52.6 MB
FedMatch 1526.0 GFLOP 115.6 MB
ProtoFSSL 447.9 GFLOP 52.6 MB
references:
As an example, consider using ResNet9 in CIFAR-10 where unlabeled data is 9.8 times more than labeled data, as in experiments in [52, 19]. In this setting, C=2​k​B𝐶2𝑘𝐵C=2kB is 13,000 times smaller than Θ=26​M​BΘ26𝑀𝐵\Theta=26MB. Table 2 shows the results, assuming that |Hr|=2subscript𝐻𝑟2|H_{r}|=2 as in [19] and A=2𝐴2A=2 as in [5]. ProtoFSSL reduces computation 71% compared to FedMatch and even 43% compared to FixMatch that is known as a lightweight SSL method. ProtoFSSL’s communication burden is less than half of FedMatch and similar to MixMatch and FedMatch.
Overall, ProtoFSSL enables inter-client knowledge sharing and pseudo-labeling in a significantly lighter way than the existing methods.

references: interacts with normalization methods and different base models. We include three normalization techniques; Batch Normalization (BN)

, Group Normalization (GN) and Static Batch Normalization (sBN).
While BN has been widely adopted, a number of studies showed that GN is superior to BN in FL settings with non-i.i.d data
as an alternative to BN, which reduces communication cost and improves privacy.

performance is improved with all three normalization methods, showing synergy between prototype-based knowledge sharing and normalization methods to improve model convergence.
However, we observe that performance gain of using each normalization method for
is different from that for FedAvg-SL. Although FedAvg provides the best accuracy with sBN and prior work has shown advantages of GN and sBN over BN,

performs best when combined with traditional BN. This verifies that the effect of normalization methods on FL is hard to be generalized; performance gain would depend on how a FL framework is designed.

is shown to work well for training a larger model ResNet17 without significant overfitting. Note that using ResNet18 can be overkill in CIFAR-10 given that FedAvg-SL does not show any performance improvement when using ResNet18 compared to ResNet9.

references: We used ResNet8 as our base network for
, and ResNet9 for baseline models, following

. Two models are identical except that ResNet8 does not have the last fully connected layer. Since our proposed method infers the probability for each class directly from prototypes, we do not need the last layer. This reduced network contributes to even smaller computation and communication overhead of

. Skip connection is used in two places. (1) from the beginning of Conv3 to the end of Conv4, (2) from the beginning of Conv7 to the end of Conv8. The network architecture of ResNet8/ResNet9 is described in

references: In each local epoch on the client, query set(
) is sampled from the unlabeled dataset for training. We use
for training. In this section, we analyze the effect of different
s. Test accuracy on CIFAR-10 dataset is reported in
. We fix all other parameters except

for the experiment. When the number of samples from unlabeled data is 10, the test accuracy is lower by 1.2%p and 1.5%p respectively, compared to the case of the number of samples from unlabeled data being 100. Test accuracy shows an increasing pattern as the number of samples from unlabeled data increases, and the increase is the largest when the number of samples increases from 30 to 50 in i.i.d case and 10 to 20 in non-i.i.d case. This result also supports that
is effective in extracting knowledge from unlabeled data.

references: We test the impact of different local epoch(
) and the experimental result on CIFAR-10 i.i.d data is summarized in

. Increasing the local epoch from 1 to 10 improves the test accuracy by 15.9%p, when there are 5 active clients and by 16.3%p when there are 20 active clients. Interestingly, when the local epoch is only 1, test accuracy is higher when there are 20 active clients, than when there are 5 active clients by 8.6%p - implying that even coarsely-learned models could improve the global model when there are more of them.

references: Given that sharing prototypes might cause privacy leaks (

), we add noise to each prototype for improving privacy and analyze how the noisy prototypes impact convergence.
Specifically, before sending their prototypes to the server, clients add noise from Gaussian distribution,
, to each value of the prototypes. For the experiments, we use
with BN and same hyperparameters as used in
shows the results, where the first row is the baseline
without noise. The results show that when the standard deviation is not too large (i.e., 10.0),
preserves model accuracy even with use of noisy prototypes. Our assumption for the robustness is that the original

combines diverse prototypes from multiple clients for pseudo-labeling and the combined knowledge is likely to be less noisy than each individual prototype; noise can be canceled to some extent while combining multiple prototypes.
